text:
The Norwegian World Cup finalist shared the award with his late coach. The family's reaction touched him.
At the end of July 2018, Einar Brynemo, the coach of Norway's best pitcher Eivind Henriksen, died. On Saturday, both were honored with the award as "Coach of the Year".
03 Nov 2019, 10:09 by Anders MÃ¸llersen
It was during an awards ceremony under the auspices of the trainer association in Norwegian athletics that the special award took place. Henriksen was called on Wednesday if he could receive a prize.
"I knew nothing else," says Henriksen the following day.
The prize turned out to be "Coach of the Year". Henriksen and Brynemo shared the award as the Norwegian Slaughter thrower has been training himself ever since the trainer passed away. Brynemo turned 71 years old.
- It was incredibly big. It was especially surprising that we had to share it. It was definitely special for an athlete to receive the award as coach of the year, but I look at the award as an award I and Einar received for the work we put together, says Henriksen.

READ THIS? Henriksen after the World Cup medal went missing: - Annoyed at being beaten by someone who was taken into doping



Eivind Henriksen (left) with leader in athletics coach association Lars Ola Sundt.ğŸ“· Private


Facts: The grounds of the trainer association
Athletics Coaches Association awards the "Coach of the Year 2019" award to Einar Brynemo:
The award is justified by Einar's extremely long and significant effort for the throwing exercises with a throwing throw as the main exercise. He has worked as a coach at all levels in Norwegian athletics and is behind achievements in international excellence, even after his passing. In addition, his special ability to disseminate is emphasized through both coach activities and written material.
Athletics Coaches Association awards the award "Coach of the Year 2019" to Eivind PrestegÃ¥rd Henriksen
The award is justified by the fact that in recent years he has been able to reach a very high international level by mainly being his own coach.
He has also been a good support and help for younger pitchers.

Died three weeks before the European Championships last year
The Oslo man has spoken to Brynemo's son after receiving the award.
- The family was very happy, says Henriksen.
- It was touching that Einar got it. It was very deserving, he adds.
Brynemo died just three weeks before the European Championships in Berlin last year, where Henriksen historically became the first Norwegian in a slug final of 60 years. The 29-year-old set two Norwegian records during the final.
This year he was in the Doha World Cup. There he was number six in his first global final, after throwing 77.38. His current Norwegian record is 78.25, set during a convention in June this year.
- Einar has certainly meant a lot over the years. He has taught me a lot during the 11-12 years he trained me. It's a coach I wouldn't have been without, â€says Henriksen.

ALSO READ: Changed training program, became injury free and crashed into the world top



Eivind Henriksen during the World Cup in Doha.ğŸ“· Vegard Wivestad GrÃ¸tt / BILDBYRÃ…N NORWAY

Going to Greece
That's why Henriksen also chose to train himself after Brynemo passed away.
- I learned a lot and I just kept on the plans we had made. I knew how to train in the future, I also had to look around and find out for myself. I also know very well what I am doing wrong, so it is possible to train yourself, says Henriksen, who is actually going to Greece in late November to look for an heir to Brynemo.
- I'm going there to train with a Greek coach. Then we will see if we can develop it into a collaboration, says the butcher.
